title: Data Centers Need to Bring Own Power Supply, Grid Watchdog Says
description: The warning escalates the watchdog’s position from just a month ago when it said the grid operated by PJM Interconnection LLC, stretching across 13 states from Virginia to Illinois, has no spare supply for new data centers and suggested developers build their own power plants.
content:
Data centers looking to connect to the largest US grid must bring their power supply, the system’s independent watchdog says.

The warning escalates the watchdog’s position from just a month ago when it said the grid operated by PJM Interconnection LLC, stretching across 13 states from Virginia to Illinois, has no spare supply for new data centers and suggested developers build their own power plants.

However, in its quarterly report released Thursday, watchdog Monitoring Analytics LLC said it “recommends that large data centers be required to bring their own generation.”

The grid is home to the highest concentration of data centers whose soaring power demand has strained and aging infrastructure, driven up costs for consumers and become a political flashpoint.

“The current supply of capacity in PJM is not adequate to meet the demand from large data center loads and will not be adequate in the foreseeable future,” the report said. “There is still time to address the issue but failure to do so will result in very high costs for other PJM customers.”

summary: The US grid's independent watchdog, Monitoring Analytics, has warned that data centers seeking access to the largest US grid must bring their own power supply. This follows a month's announcement that the grid, operated by PJM Interconnection LLC, had no spare supply for new data centers and suggested developers build own power plants. The watchdog warns that failure to address this issue will result in high costs for other PJM customers.
shortSummary: The US Grid Watchdog advises that large data centers must provide their own power supply to meet increasing demands and reduce costs.
argos_summary: Data centers seeking to connect to the PJM Interconnection grid must now provide their own power supply, according to a report from Monitoring Analytics LLC. This recommendation comes as the grid, which spans 13 states, faces a significant strain from the increasing power demands of data centers, leading to higher costs for consumers. The report warns that the current capacity is insufficient to meet future demands, and failure to address this could result in substantial costs for other customers.
